School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University No. 92 Weijin Road Nankai District Tianjin 300072 China Graphical abstract Molybdenum-based catalysts, especially MoS2 have been widely applied to the hydrogenation reaction system for the excellent catalytic and sulfur-resistant performance. As a typical transition metal carbide, there are few reports on the application of Mo2C to sulfur-resistant methanation. Herein, a series of Mo2C/ZrO2 were obtained by coprecipitation and impregnation methods as well as applied to sulfur-resistant methanation. Effects of Mo2C loading and the water bath temperature during coprecipitation on the catalytic activity of Mo2C/ZrO2 were further studied, with emphasis on the change of structures and active components affected by the water bath temperature. The catalyst (15 wt.% Mo2C loading) obtained by coprecipitation at the 80 °C water bath exhibited the highest CO conversion (maintained above 60% under the experimental condition). The combined techniques of N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, H2 temperature-programmed reduction were also used to characterize the as-obtained catalysts. The study, with insights of the transformation of Mo species and ZrO2 support during the preparation process, provides the possibility for the further application of Mo2C/ZrO2. Keywords Molybdenum carbide ZrO2 support Preparation method Sulfur-resistant methanation 1 Introduction Synthetic natural gas (SNG) technology is a great potential approach to converting carbonaceous resources into methane, which is of great signification for efficient and clean utilization of coal [1,2] and other resources. In the process of producing SNG from coal, one key step is methanation reaction which determines the quality of SNG production as well as the economic efficiency of the whole process [3]. At present, the commercial catalysts used in the methanation reaction are mainly supported catalysts with nickel-containing species as the active component [4,5], which have been proved to higher CO conversion and CH4 selectivity. As is known to all that nickel-based catalyst is prone to deactivate for the deposition of carbon on its surface when the ratio of H2/CO is less than 3. Therefore, the water-gas-shift process is necessary for adjusting contents of H2 and CO before methanation [6]. In addition, considering that sulfur components are often found in the raw materials of SNG process such as coal and biomass, a desulfurization process is required to prevent the catalysts from being poisoned and deactivated in a sulfur-containing atmosphere. These adjustment and purification processes increase the complexity of the SNG process as well as the investment in process equipment, thereby reducing the economic benefits of SNG products. In contrast, water-gas-shift and desulfurization are not essential during the process of the sulfur-resistant methanation due to the application of molybdenum-based catalysts. In this way, the process of CO hydrogenation (1) and water-gas-shift (2) occurs simultaneously in one process, and the reaction can be summarized as the reaction Eq. (3). (1) C O + 3 H 2 ⇌ C H 4 + H 2 O (2) C O + H 2 O ⇌ H 2 + C O 2 (3) 2 C O + 2 H 2 ⇌ C H 4 + C O 2 Mo-based catalyst is the main catalyst used in sulfur-resistant methanation process for its excellent performance on water-gas-shift and methanation [7,8]. Additionally, when applied to sulfur-resistant methanation process, MoS2 is the main catalytic active component in sulfur-containing atmospheres which helps the catalyst maintain stable catalytic performance [9]. Therefore MoS2 has been widely used in the hydrogenation reaction system in sulfur-containing atmosphere such as hydro- desulfurization (HDS) [10,11], hydro-denitrification (HDN) [12], hydro-deoxygenation (HDO) [7]. In recent years, MoS2 has also gradually been applied in sulfur-resistant methanation reaction [13]. It is no doubt that Mo-based catalyst has obvious advantages of simplifying the synthetic natural gas production process and improving its economic efficiency in the sulfur-resistant methanation reaction. However, the relatively lower catalytic activity is still the main factor limiting the industrial application of these potential catalysts. The Pt-like catalytic properties of transition metal carbides were first introduced by Levy and Boudart in 1973 based on the study of tungsten carbide (WC) [14]. Subsequently, as a typical transition metal carbide, the catalytic performance of molybdenum carbide was also studied [15,16]. The CO methanation performance of Co/β-Mo2C catalyst was studied by Huo et al. [17], their work showed that the Co-β-Mo2C catalyst exhibited high activity and stability during the process for its Co3Mo3C structure. A group of K/Mo2C catalysts doped with Ni, Cu and Mn were synthesized in the study of Liakakou and Heracleous [18]. The obtained Ni/K/Mo2C has good catalytic performance, whose CO conversion and selectivity of higher alcohol are 23.2% and 30.5%, respectively. But as yet, there is little report on the application of molybdenum carbide catalysts in sulfur-resistant methanation. The support often interacts with the active component and affects the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Nowadays, the most commonly used support of Mo-based catalysts is γ-Al2O3, and it has many good characteristics such as porousness, high dispersion as well as large specific surface area, etc. In comparison with γ-Al2O3, ZrO2 is a kind of transition metal oxide that combines acid-base and redox properties [19]. Li et al. [20] prepared MoO3/ZrO2 catalyst by one-step coprecipitation. When the sample was applied to sulfur-resistant methanation, the CO conversion is 90.06% and close to the equilibrium conversion under the given condition. Benito et al. [21] studied the performance of ZrO2-supported Ni, Co and Cu catalysts in ethanol steam reforming system, the result indicated that Ni/t-ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the highest selectivity in hydrogen production. Hence, the attempt to load Mo2C on ZrO2 support and apply the catalyst in sulfur-resistant methanation is worth exploring based on reported works, but there is no relevant literature at present. In this work, Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts were synthesized by impregnation and coprecipitation methods, respectively. The effect of preparation methods on the sulfur-resistant methanation performance of Mo2C/ZrO2 was studied. Furthermore, the optimal loading dosage of Mo2C and water bath temperature during coprecipitation were also investigated. All these obtained catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, H2 temperature- programmed reduction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts were synthesized by coprecipitation and impregnation methods [22], respectively. Firstly, the molybdenum carbide precursor solution was obtained by dissolving ammonium heptamolybdate (AHM, (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O) and hexamethylenetetramine (HMT, C6H12N4) at a fixed mole ratio of 1:9 in the 15% NH3·H2O solution. The impregnation method required to impregnate commercial ZrO2 support and self-made Zr(OH)4 in the molybdenum carbide precursor solution to prepare Mo2C/ZrO2-IM1 and Mo2C/ZrO2-IM2 catalyst precursors. The impregnated precursors need to be dried at room temperature for 48 h, and then 80 °C drying in a vacuum oven for 3 h before the subsequent treatment. The self-made Zr(OH)4 support mentioned above was obtained through precipitating zirconium nitrate by aqueous ammonia in the laboratory, while the commercial ZrO2 support was bought from Qianye Non-metallic Material Co. Ltd, China. Mo2C/ZrO2-COP precursor was prepared by coprecipitation with molybdenum carbide precursor solution and the zirconium nitrate solution. The method requires thorough mixing of these two solutions under a constant water bath at a suitable temperature (60, 80 and 90 °C in this work). After a 12 h aging process, the fine mixture was filtered, washed and then dried overnight at 80 °C in a vacuum oven. Carbonization and passivation were also needed in the synthesis process of Mo2C/ZrO2. The carbonization of precursors was carried out in a 700 °C tube furnace for 2 h, and a stream of nitrogen was introduced into the furnace during this process. All samples need to be passivated in a mixed atmosphere of 1 vol.% O2/N2 for 2 h after carbonization to prevent the catalyst from being deactivated in air. A series of Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts with 10, 15, 20 and 25 wt.% Mo2C loadings were prepared by adjusting the ratio of molybdenum carbide precursor solution and zirconium nitrate solution during the coprecipitation process, and were marked as 10%-Mo2C/ZrO2, 15%-Mo2C/ZrO2, 20%-Mo2C/ZrO2 and 25%-Mo2C/ZrO2, respectively. While the Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts containing 15 wt.% Mo2C prepared by coprecipitation under different water bath temperature were named as Mo2C/ZrO2-60, Mo2C/ZrO2-80 and Mo2C/ZrO2-90, respectively. 2.2 Characterization A Tristar-3000 physisorption analyzer (Micromeritics, America) was employed to characterize surface physical properties of Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts. Before analysis, all the samples need to be degassed for 3 h at 300 °C in the atmosphere of nitrogen. Combined with Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation and BJH model, the specific surface area (SBET ), average pore size, pore volume and its distribution of samples can be obtained through nitrogen adsorption-desorption. A D/MAX 2500 V/PC diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) with a nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.54056 Å) which worked under conditions of 40 kV and 100 mA was employed to measure X-ray diffraction patterns of the catalysts. All catalysts were scanned between 10 and 80° at a speed of 5°/min. Raman spectra were obtained by an InVia-Reflex Raman spectrometer (Rwnishaw, Britain) with a 6 mW He-Ne laser whose emission wavelength is 532 nm. H2-TPR was characterized by an AutoChem 2910 chemistry analyzer with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) from Micromeritics corporation, America. The catalyst needed to be purged by nitrogen at 200 °C for 40 min before experiment. H2-TPR test was in the atmosphere of 10 vol. % H2/Ar, the adsorption capacity of catalysts was collected between 60 and 1000 °C while the heating rate of the apparatus is 10 °C/min. 2.3 Activity evaluation To evaluate the catalytic activity of Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts, a fixed-bed reactor made by stainless steel was chosen [23]. Before evaluation, the catalyst was sandwiched between two layers of quartz and placed in the constant temperature zone of the reactor. The reduction of catalysts was carried out in pure hydrogen flow (100 mL/min) at 400 °C for 2 h. Conditions of methanation were selected as follows: reactor bed temperature was stable at 550 °C, the pressure was 3 MPa, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV, L(gas)/g(catalyst)/h) was 5000, the ratio of CO/H2 was fixed at 1.0 in the raw gas as well as the H2S content is 1500 ppm. The catalytic activity data of the catalyst for 20 h were collected in this work. The outlet gas phase products were analyzed online by a SP3420 gas chromatography (Beifen-Ruili, China) equipped with TCD and FID for quantitative analysis of products. The CO conversion, the selectivity of CH4, C2H6 and C3+ during methanation were used to represent the performance of obtained catalysts and were calculated in terms of the formulas below: (4) C ( C O ) = n ( c o , i n ) - n ( c o , o u t ) n ( c o , i n ) × 100 % (5) S ( C H 4 ) = n ( C H 4 , o u t ) n ( C H 4 , o u t ) + 2 × n ( C 2 H 6 , o u t ) + 3 × n ( C 3 + , o u t ) × 100 % (6) S ( C 2 H 6 ) = 2 × n ( C 2 H 6 , o u t ) n ( C H 4 , o u t ) + 2 × n ( C 2 H 6 , o u t ) + 3 × n ( C 3 + , o u t ) × 100 % (7) S ( C 3 + ) = 3 × n ( C 3 + ) n ( C H 4 , o u t ) + 2 × n ( C 2 H 6 , o u t ) + 3 × n ( C 3 + , o u t ) × 100 % Carbon balance during the reaction is within ±3% for all the methanation tests, indicating the believability of the experiment. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of preparation method on Mo2C/ZrO2 3.1.1 Characterization Table 1 presents the obtained textural property data of Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts synthesized by impregnation and coprecipitation. These results are consistent with conclusion of the literatures [24,25] that BET surface of catalysts with ZrO2 support is much less than those loaded on γ-Al2O3 support. Among these catalysts, Mo2C/ZrO2-COP prepared by coprecipitation gets the largest BET surface and offers the favorable condition for the uniform distribution of Mo2C active species. At the same time, in comparison to the sample synthesized by impregnation method, Mo2C/ZrO2-COP has the moderate pore volume and size. Fig. 1 shows the pore size distribution of three different Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts. The result suggests that Mo2C/ZrO2-COP has the most probable aperture of about 4 nm while Mo2C/ZrO2-IM2 is about 3.5 nm. These mesoporous structure is advantageous for the loading of the active components and offers good catalytic performance to samples. Fig. 2 give out the crystalline structure of the obtained catalysts. Notable that the peak at 2θ = 39.4° was found in the pattern of Mo2C/ZrO2-IM1 to prove that Mo2C has been successfully loaded on the support (PDF# 35-0787). From XRD patterns of Mo2C/ZrO2-IM2 and Mo2C/ZrO2-COP, peaks at 2θ = 30.2°, 35.25°, 50.4°,60.2° and 62.9° that attributed to t-ZrO2 (PDF# 50-1089) were found. These peaks show that the support of samples synthesized by the coprecipitation method and the impregnation method are t-ZrO2. While in the pattern of Mo2C/ZrO2-IM1 which was impregnated with the commercial ZrO2, a group of peaks at 2θ = 28.1°, 31.5°, 50.1° and 60.1° prove that the support is mainly m-ZrO2. 3.1.2 Catalytic activity evaluation Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts made by different methods were packed in the stainless steel fixed-bed reactor to investigate the methanation performance. The H2S concentration is fixed at 1500 ppm in the reaction system. CO conversion and selectivity data are presented in Fig. 3 and Table 2 , respectively. Mo2C/ZrO2-COP that prepared by coprecipitation method exhibits the highest CO conversion during the evaluation of these three catalysts and is stable at about 58%. The CO conversion of Mo2C/ZrO2-IM2 was observed a gradual decrease as the reaction proceeding, and after about 15 h it tended to be stable and almost the same as that of Mo2C/ZrO2-IM1. Combined with textural property data mentioned above, it can be considered that the poor catalytic performance of Mo2C/ZrO2-IM1 at the beginning of the reaction can be attributed to its relative small BET surface as well as the poor pore size distribution. By analyzing XRD results of Mo2C/ZrO2-IM1 and Mo2C/ZrO2-COP, it can be inferred that the methanation performance of Mo2C/ZrO2 may be linked to the crystalline phase of ZrO2 support and is affected by the different preparation method (t-ZrO2 support of catalysts made by coprecipitation and m-ZrO2 support of catalysts made by impregnating with commercial ZrO2 powder). This is consistent with previous works of Teak [26] and Benito [20] that supports of different crystalline phases in catalysts will provide different catalytic properties to the samples. The selectivity of both Mo2C/ZrO2-IM1 and Mo2C/ZrO2-COP is similar, while Mo2C/ZrO2-IM2 has the lowest CH4 selectivity of 89.1%. The high CH4 selectivity also prove that the catalyst is suitable for methanation. Based on the above characterization and catalytic evaluation results, a conclusion can be drawn that the catalysts obtained by the coprecipitation method has the best catalytic activity during the process of direct methanation. And the subsequent studies in this paper will continue to explore the Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts prepared by coprecipitation method. 3.2 Effect of MoC2 loading on Mo2C/ZrO2 3.2.1 Characterization Samples loaded 10, 15, 20 and 25 wt.% MoC2 were synthesized by coprecipitation to investigate how the MoC2 loading affects the sulfur-resistant methanation performance of Mo2C/ZrO2. Table 3 shows the surface physical property date of catalysts with different MoC2 loading before and after methanation which were collected from the N2 adsorption-desorption experiment. For the catalysts before the reaction, the BET surface, pore volume and pore size are similar, indicating that the increase of molybdenum carbide loading has no obvious effects on the textural properties of different samples. Compare the catalysts before and after methanation, it can be clearly found that the BET surface of all samples after methanation reduced greatly while the pore size increased simultaneously. The decreasing BET surface and the increasing pore size of catalysts are often accompanied by loss and sintering of surface active components, which is usually an important factor for the decline in the catalytic performance. The reason for this phenomenon may be that in the course of the reaction, when the catalyst is subjected to high temperature and high pressure treatment, the adjacent pore structures are destroyed, and thus the average pore diameter increased. To further studying whether the different Mo2C loading affect the crystal structure of Mo2C/ZrO2 and the change of active components during the process of methanation, both fresh and spent catalysts were characterized by XRD. The results (Fig. 4 ) show that in patterns of fresh catalysts, peaks at 2θ = 28.2, 31.5, 34.2, 49.3, 50.1° that attributed to t-ZrO2 (PDF# 50-1089) indicates the crystalline phase of ZrO2 support, and the fact that Mo2C is well dispersed on ZrO2. It was also proved by the reason that no peaks of Mo2C is presented. Notable that when the loading of molybdenum carbide reached 25 wt.%, three peaks of MoO2 (2θ = 26.1, 36.9, 53.6°, PDF# 65-5787) were found in the XRD patterns, and the formation of MoO2 can be due to the passivation product of excessive Mo2C on the surface of ZrO2. In addition, another peak at 2θ = 23.1° was also observed due to the fact that the interaction between Mo2C and support leads to the formation of ZrMo2O8 (PDF＃ 39-1438). The XRD patterns of recovered catalysts appear that both t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2 exist in samples simultaneously. It suggests that all the catalysts after methanation have undergone crystal phase transformation. The same transformation phenomenon has also been mentioned in the work of Chen et al. [27] and has been proved to affect the methanation activity of MoO3/ZrO2. After methanation, characteristic peaks of MoO2 are still recognized in the pattern of spent 25%-Mo2C/ZrO2 catalyst because of the passivation operation in catalysts recovering process. However, in comparison of fresh catalysts with samples after methanation, the peak at 2θ = 23.1° disappear in all the patterns of spent catalyst. This disappearance may be due to the fact that most of the ZrMo2O8 is reduced during the hydrogen reduction process and only a small amount of ZrMo2O8 remained in amorphous state. The change of ZrMo2O8 phase before and after the reaction will be further discussed in combination with the characteristic results of Raman spectroscopy and H2-TPR. Notable that no new sulfides were found according to the XRD patterns of catalysts after methanation, which indicates that Mo2C/ZrO2 has sulfur resistance and the active components can remain stable in a sulfur-containing atmosphere. Since there is no crystal information of Mo2C is given from the XRD patterns, Raman spectroscopy was employed to further explore amorphous materials of fresh catalysts. From Fig. 5 , all the samples exhibit several peaks located at ∼ 149, ∼ 272, ∼ 321, ∼ 426 and ∼ 643 cm−1, and these peaks have been reported to be characteristic peaks of t- ZrO2 according to literatures [28–30]. The result is also consistent with the information given by XRD (Fig. 4 Before Reaction). Zaidi et al. [31] reported that there are two characteristic bands in the Raman spectra of reduced Mo2C at ∼818 and ∼ 989 cm−1. In Fig. 5, two characteristic bands were also observed close to bands mentioned above at ∼ 817 and ∼ 985 cm−1, indicating the existence of Mo2C. The existing state of the material always results in different vibration frequencies. To molybdenum species, the position of peaks between 800 and 1000 cm−1 depends on the treatment process, loading dosage as well as the interaction between active component and the support [32,33]. Several characteristic bands of ZrMo2O8 at ∼ 747, ∼ 942 and ∼ 1001 cm−1 are presented in Fig. 5, among which the peak at ∼ 942 cm−1 can be ascribed to O-Mo-O vibrational mode of ZrMo2O8 according to literatures [27,30,34]. By comparing the intensities of peaks attributed to ZrMo2O8 and Mo2C of the catalysts with different loadings, it is known that as the loading increases, ZrMo2O8 content of the catalyst increases. It can be considered that Mo2C has a maximum saturate capacity on ZrO2 support. This also explains why the characteristic peak of crystalline ZrMo2O8 appears in the XRD result of 25%-Mo2C/ZrO2 (Fig. 4). Notable that ZrMo2O8 was proved to have low reaction activity during methanation [35], thus high Mo2C loading may adversely affect the catalytic performance of Mo2C/ZrO2. H2-TPR profiles (Fig. 6 ) embody the interaction between active components and supports of Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts. Two peaks correspond to the reduction of molybdenum species are apparent at ∼ 400 °C and ∼ 740 °C. Lødeng et al. [36] have reported that an obvious peak of unsupported Mo2C material was observed at about 300 °C. In consideration of the strong interaction between Mo2C and ZrO2, the consumption peak at ∼ 400 °C may be attributed to passivation products of Mo2C. When the loading of Mo2C is more than 15 wt.%, an additional shoulder appears at ∼ 470 °C can be explained by the reduction of ZrMo2O8 [37] which was observed in X-ray diffraction patterns (Fig. 4). According to the literature [38], the peak at ∼ 750 °C can be ascribed to the further reduction of tetrahedral molybdenum (Mo+4→Mo0) for the strong metal-support interactions. The same phenomena have been reported on other Mo-supported materials like MoO3/γ-Al2O3 [39] and MoO3/TiO2 [40]. 3.2.2 Catalytic activity evaluation All the catalysts exhibit high methane selectivity in this reaction system and stable at about 95%. The CO conversion results show a trend of first rising and then decreasing as the dosage of Mo2C increases. The CO conversion of 25%-Mo2C/ZrO2 is the lowest during the process of methanation in Fig. 7 , this low CO conversion may because of the residual ZrMo2O8 after reduction or the aggregation of the excessive Mo2C. For the rest of samples, the performance of 15%-Mo2C/ZrO2 is better than others and has a CO conversion of about 60%. Therefore, it can be considered that the sulfur-resistant methanation activity of Mo2C/ZrO2 is positively correlated with the content of Mo2C component, and the extra Mo2C may interact with the support to generate ZrMo2O8. Meanwhile, CO conversion of catalysts were observed to decrease with time, this phenomenon may because of the crystal phase transition of ZrO2 support observed from XRD patterns (Fig. 4). As a consequence, the optimal loading of Mo2C on ZrO2 support can be regarded as 15 wt.%, at where the catalytic active component is uniformly dispersed on the support and the sample has the best performance in sulfur-resistant methanation. Consistent to the previous reports [27], the XRD results of catalysts before and after reaction give out that the transition of t-ZrO2→m-ZrO2 in this reaction may also affect the performance of obtained Mo2C/ZrO2, while this transition plays a disadvantageous role in this work. Notice that the XRD result presents the good sulfur-resistance property of Mo2C/ZrO2 for no appearance of sulfide phases. 3.3 Effect of water bath temperature during the process of coprecipitation A key step of coprecipitation method in preparing Mo2C/ZrO2 is to precipitate the precursor solution under water bath heating conditions where the precipitation process is greatly affected by the temperature of the water bath. To investigate how the water bath temperature affects the properties of Mo2C/ZrO2, samples prepared in different water bath (60, 80 and 90 °C) were obtained and discussed in this following section. 3.3.1 Characterization The influence of water bath temperature during coprecipitation of Mo2C/ZrO2 was studied with the physical adsorption apparatus thorough a N2 adsorption- desorption experiment. The BET surface of different catalyst displayed in Table 4 tells that the raise of water bath temperature will lead to a slight drop in the BET surface. However, there is no significant difference in the pore volume and pore size of different samples. Fig. 8 shows the pore size distribution of different Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts. It indicates that the higher water bath temperature will result in a drop in the amount of pore near the most probable aperture. Generally speaking, the different water bath temperatures during the preparation process have no significant influence on the catalysts textural properties. Fig. 9 displays the XRD patterns of different samples. The obtained consequences are the same as the previous experiments, that is, the support of the catalyst prepared by coprecipitation is mainly t-ZrO2 and independent of the water bath temperature in the preparation process. However, characteristic peaks of samples prepared at different water bath temperatures are not exactly the same. Different from (b) and (c) of Fig. 9, the sample prepared by coprecipitation at the water bath temperature of 60 °C was observed a characteristic peak at 2θ = 23.1° which have been proven to belong to ZrMo2O8 in accordance with the foregoing XRD and Raman spectra results. This indicates that the higher water bath temperature during the preparation process is beneficial for the uniform dispersion of Mo2C on ZrO2 and reduces the interaction between them, thus inhibiting the formation of ZrMo2O8. It should be pointed out that when the water bath temperature is 90 °C, a series of characteristic peaks at 2θ = 26.1, 36.9 and 53.6° which present the existence of MoO2 (PDF# 65-5787) are found, but the similar phenomena did not appear in other samples. In the synthesis process of Mo2C by AHM and HMT, Zhang et al. [41] reported that one important factor is the formation of Mo-HMT complex. They found that when there is no Mo-HMT complex was found in the precursor solution, the products were proved to be MoO2 after calcination according to the result of X-ray diffraction. Thus, the appearance of crystalline MoO2 in samples may be due to the fact that higher water bath temperature is unfavorable to the formation of Mo-HMT complex. Characteristic bonds attributed to Mo species are mainly located between 700 and 1000 cm−1 in Raman spectra (Fig. 10 ). Not like Mo2C/ZrO2-60, peaks attributed to ZrMo2O8 were not found in spectra of samples water bath heating at the temperature of 80 or 90 °C. It was consistent with XRD results in Fig. 9. However, a slight shift in peaks attributed to Mo2C (812 and 984 cm−1 of Mo2C/ZrO2-60) was observed in the other Raman spectra. Previous work reported by Frauwallner et al. [42] demonstrate that such a slight shift is because of the partial substitution of Mo = O for Mo = C in the sample. Therefore, these two shifting peaks (∼814 and ∼995 cm−1) can also be ascribed to the formation of MoO2. The results of Raman spectra and XRD show the water bath temperature affects a lot on the obtained samples during the coprecipitation process. The higher water bath temperature will facilitate the dispersion of Mo species on the support and can refrain the formation of ZrMo2O8, but may prevent the formation of the active component of catalysts, which is not conducive to the preparation of Mo2C/ZrO2. Similar to the aforementioned results, all catalysts showed two hydrogen- consuming peaks at ∼ 400 °C and ∼ 740 °C. And in the foregoing discussion, these two peaks were proved to be reduction of passivation products of Mo2C and tetrahedral molybdenum (Mo+4→Mo0), respectively. It can be seen from the result that the shoulders belonging to ZrMo2O8 did not appear in the profiles of (b) and (c), which proved that there was no ZrMo2O8 in both samples. Another point to note is that the hydrogen absorption peaks of the samples obtained at 80 and 90 °C water bath have a slight movement towards the high temperature zone. Considering that the peak positions of Mo2C/ZrO2-80 and Mo2C/ZrO2-90 are different from those of Mo2C/ZrO2-60, it is speculated that the shift may be caused by the formation of MoO2 in the samples (Fig. 11 ). 3.3.2 Catalytic activity evaluation Fig. 12 showed that the sulfur-resistant methanation activity of Mo2C/ZrO2 was also affected by the temperature of the water bath during the preparation process. For all catalysts, there is little difference in the selectivity of methane. Mo2C/ZrO2-80 exhibited the highest CO conversion under the experimental condition and maintained above 60% within 20 h, while Mo2C/ZrO2-90 had a relatively lower CO conversion. Discussions on results of XRD and Raman spectra indicate that higher water bath temperature will reduce the interaction between Mo2C and ZrO2, thereby reducing the ZrMo2O8 phase, but also lead to the formation of MoO2 rather than Mo2C on the surface of ZrO2. Thus it can be inferred that the methanation activities of both ZrMo2O8 and MoO2 are not as good as that of Mo2C. A conclusion can also be drawn that while reducing the interaction, only a small amount of MoO2 was formed in the samples coprecipitated in the water bath with the temperature of 80 °C, which ensured the efficient utilization of Mo atoms and guaranteed the highest sulfur-tolerant methanation activity of Mo2C/ZrO2 catalysts. Besides, combined with the discussion in 3.2, this work also considers that the crystal phase transition of t-ZrO2→m-ZrO2 during the methanation process is an important factor for the methanation performance drop of Mo2C/ZrO2 as the reaction proceeds. 4 Conclusion Mo2C/ZrO2 were obtained and applied to sulfur-resistant methanation in this work. The results of characterization and evaluation of catalysts prepared by different method suggest that the support of catalysts prepared by coprecipitation is mainly t-ZrO2 and the catalyst presents the highest CO conversion during methanation. We further studied the effect of Mo2C loading and the water bath temperature during coprecipitation. In combination with the various characterizations (XRD, Raman spectroscopy and H2-TPR), for the result that the excessive Mo2C is easy to interact with support to form ZrMo2O8, we recognized the optimal Mo2C loading on ZrO2 is 15 wt.%. The proper water bath temperature in the process of coprecipitation is also found to be 80 °C where the interaction between activity components and support was lowered to guarantee the full use of Mo species. In conclusion, the obtained Mo2C/ZrO2 (15 wt.% Mo2C, coprecipitated in the 80 °C water bath) exhibits a stable CO conversion of 60% and a methane selectivity of 91.5% within 20 h. What’s more, the fact that no new sulfide species were found in spent catalysts according to the XRD patterns also indicates the good sulfur-resistance of Mo2C/ZrO2. coredata.dc:description: Molybdenum-based catalysts, especially MoS2 have been widely applied to the hydrogenation reaction system for the excellent catalytic and sulfur-resistant performance. As a typical transition metal carbide, there are few reports on the application of Mo2C to sulfur-resistant methanation. Herein, a series of Mo2C/ZrO2 were obtained by coprecipitation and impregnation methods as well as applied to sulfur-resistant methanation. Effects of Mo2C loading and the water bath temperature during coprecipitation on the catalytic activity of Mo2C/ZrO2 were further studied, with emphasis on the change of structures and active components affected by the water bath temperature. The catalyst (15 wt.% Mo2C loading) obtained by coprecipitation at the 80 °C water bath exhibited the highest CO conversion (maintained above 60% under the experimental condition). The combined techniques of N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, H2 temperature-programmed reduction were also used to characterize the as-obtained catalysts. The study, with insights of the transformation of Mo species and ZrO2 support during the preparation process, provides the possibility for the further application of Mo2C/ZrO2.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of preparation method and Mo2C loading on the Mo2C/ZrO2 catalyst for sulfur-resistant methanation
